review.title: Symmetric Weighted First-Order Model Counting
review.abstract: The FO Model Counting problem (FOMC) is the following: given a sentence $\Phi$ in FO and a number $n$, compute the number of models of $\Phi$ over a domain of size $n$; the Weighted variant (WFOMC) generalizes the problem by associating a weight to each tuple and defining the weight of a model to be the product of weights of its tuples. In this paper we study the complexity of the symmetric WFOMC, where all tuples of a given relation have the same weight. Our motivation comes from an important application, inference in Knowledge Bases with soft constraints, like Markov Logic Networks, but the problem is also of independent theoretical interest. We study both the data complexity, and the combined complexity of FOMC and WFOMC. For the data complexity we prove the existence of an FO$^{3}$ formula for which FOMC is #P$_1$-complete, and the existence of a Conjunctive Query for which WFOMC is #P$_1$-complete. We also prove that all $\gamma$-acyclic queries have polynomial time data complexity. For the combined complexity, we prove that, for every fragment FO$^{k}$, $k\geq 2$, the combined complexity of FOMC (or WFOMC) is #P-complete.

metadata.title: Symmetric Weighted First-Order Model Counting

sections.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION
sections.text: Large knowledge bases, such as Yago [19], Nell [2], DeepDive [6], Reverb [11], Microsoft Probase [43], or Google's Knowledge Vault [8], have millions to billions of insecure tuples. These systems scan large corporations of texts, such as the Web or complete collections of journalism articles, automatically containing billions of structured facts that represent large accumulations of knowledge. For illustration, Google's Knowledge Vault [8] contains 1.6B triples of form (subject, predicate, object), for example < / m / 02mjmr, / people _ of _ birth / m _ 0 _ > where / m / 02mjmr systems is the freebase id for Barack Obama, and / m / 02hrh0 _ is the id for Honolulu.

The answer was shown by Jager and Van den Jaeck.

sections.heading: Results on the Combined Complexity
sections.text: Our main result in terms of combined complexity is as follows: We show that the combined complexity of the FOMC for FOK is complete for each k ≥ 2 # P; membership is a standard application of Scott's reduction, while hardness is created by reducing the problem of model counting for Boolean formulas. Remember that vocabulary σ is always assumed to be fixed: if it is allowed to be part of the input, then every Boolean formula is a special case of a FO0 formula, creating a new relational symbol of precision zero for each Boolean variable, and all hardness results for Boolean formulas are immediately transferred to FO0.

sections.heading: The Associated Decision Problem
sections.text: We also discuss and present some new results on the decision problem related to (W) FOMC: "Is there a model over a range of size n?" The variant of data complexity is of course the problem of spectral membership, which was completely solved by Jones and Selman [23] by proving that the class of spectra corresponds to NETIME, that is, {Spec (N) | Φ FO} = NETIME. Their result assumes that the input n is represented in binary form, hence the input size is log n. In this essay we are interested in the uneven representation of n, also referred to as total notation, in which case NETIME is of course identified with NP1. Fagin proved that in the overall notation {Spec (E) the total notation, {Spec (FOFO) | Special 6, Part 2] is a complex ability.

sections.heading: 5. CONCLUSIONS
sections.text: In this paper, we discuss the symmetric weighted FO Model Counting problem. Our motivation stems from the probable conclusion in Markov Logic Networks, with applications to modern, large knowledge bases, but the problem is also of independent theoretical interest. We examined both the data complexity and the combined complexity. For the data complexity, we established for the first time the existence of an FO set for which the symmetric model counting problem is # P1hard, and also the existence of a subjunctive query for which the problem of symmetric weighted model counting is # P1-hard. We also showed that for all g-acyclic subjunctive queries WFOMC can be calculated in polynomial time. For the combined complexity, we demonstrated a narrow limit of # P completeness for FO2. We also discussed the associated decision problem.

By allowing runtimes O(n) with a > 1, the lemma implies: #P1 = {f | ∃Φ ∈ FO ,∀n : f(n) = bFOMC(Φ, n)/n!c}; this is an extension of the classic result by Jones and Selman [23], which, restated for the tally notation says NP1 = {Spec(Φ) | Φ ∈ FO} (see [12], [9, Sec.

By allowing runtimes O(n) with a > 1, the lemma implies: #P1 = {f | ∃Φ ∈ FO ,∀n : f(n) = bFOMC(Φ, n)/n!c}; this is an extension of the classic result by Jones and Selman [23], which, restated for the tally notation says NP1 = {Spec(Φ) | Φ ∈ FO} (see [12], [9, Sec.
To prove the theorem, we use an equivalent definition of γ-acyclicity given by Fagin [14], which we give here together with our algorithm for computing Pr(Q).
Vardi [40] proved that the model checking problem, “given Φ and a structure D, is Φ true in D?” is PSPACE-complete.
This problem is #P-hard [33].

metadata.abstractText: The FO Model Counting problem (FOMC) is the following: given a sentence Φ in FO and a number n, compute the number of models of Φ over a domain of size n; the Weighted variant (WFOMC) generalizes the problem by associating a weight to each tuple and defining the weight of a model to be the product of weights of its tuples. In this paper we study the complexity of the symmetric WFOMC, where all tuples of a given relation have the same weight. Our motivation comes from an important application, inference in Knowledge Bases with soft constraints, like Markov Logic Networks, but the problem is also of independent theoretical interest. We study both the data complexity, and the combined complexity of FOMC and WFOMC. For the data complexity we prove the existence of an FO formula for which FOMC is #P1complete, and the existence of a Conjunctive Query for which WFOMC is #P1-complete. We also prove that all γacyclic queries have polynomial time data complexity. For the combined complexity, we prove that, for every fragment FO, k ≥ 2, the combined complexity of FOMC (or WFOMC) is
